job_title: Clinical Education Coordinator in New Orleans, LA
pros:
The people who are served.
The building itself.
The long-term employees.
cons: My position was weird. I worked in the Clinical Ed office and ran their LMS. There were a lot of fights between employees - some of them were actively trying to get the director fired. He was fine but avoided the office because people were trying to get him fired all of the time. I ended up learning the system better than other users, but we didn't utilize it correctly because we were dependent on other department's processes that were not compatible. I realized quickly that things change at a snail's pace there and my enthusiasm wasn't a good fit. Alas - I'm a sucker and continued to do my job 3 evenings a week for 3 months and they never even interviewed anyone for my position.

job_title: MHT in New Orleans, LA
pros: Develop friends through collective suffering
cons: management if you even have any

cons: Low pay, No team work, NO Accountability, allows people to talk down at you

review_title: Great experience, looks great on your resume, not a good company overall
job_title: Registered Nurse in New Orleans, LA
pros: Level 1 Trauma Center so you are getting the best experience possible. Tons of opportunities to sharpen your skills as a nurse.
cons: Severely understaffed, do not value employees or treat fairly, little to no opportunity for growth. Employees treated TERRIBLE during pandemic. I got COVID from this hospital and was not compensated in the least bit. My unit was one of the only units who did not receive COVID pay, yet we are putting our lives at risk every day dealing with COVID positive patients. The hospital did not compensate me for the PTO I had to use while out with COVID. THEY DO NOT CARE ABOUT THEIR EMPLOYEES!!!

review_title: Great, if you are wearing rose colored glasses.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Orleans, LA
pros: Good leadership and a change in the way things are being run.  This is not the state run hospital any longer, this is a private hospital company being run professionally.  They are on the right track.  the new building will be awesome.  Never worked in $1.3 B hospital - it will be nice to work at a place with all new equipment
cons: This is a hospital in transition from state run to private.  There is a cultural change, but if you want to be a part of a team moving toward a patient focus, you should try it.  I have loved my first several months.  It is busy but exciting.

review_title: If you are a male, you should probably skip this one
job_title: Medical in New Orleans, LA
pros:
Great healthcare benefits and beautiful facility. An awesome learning experience. 
This is an advanced teaching hospital and one of the most important in the city of New Orleans.
cons:
Poor management who favor only women. If you're a male RN, be prepared to be attacked quote often for smallest things, while your female counterparts kill patients and don't get reprimanded.
Hard work definitely goes unnoticed. A pat on the back isn't expected, but treating someone with common respect and decency is.
UMC has a policy, which is no issue or con at all. The problem is, there own staff and management do not adhere to those policies. They pick and choose which rules they want to follow.
How do you like that burger? Not with a side of gender discrimination.

job_title: Surgical Technologist II in New Orleans, LA
pros: We are a level 1 trauma center and teaching facility. We rarely have standard cases so it keeps you interested, on your toes and makes you feel like you really helped somebody in need.
cons: It's resident ran meaning the staff let's the resident use whatever supplies they want which means your nurse and yourself are constantly running for supplies. Our management is terrible and rarely offer a helping hand. Our educator can not run a room and doesnt know how use more than half of our equipment.

job_title: Radiologic Technologist in New Orleans, LA
pros: Experience and the Employees are about all that come to mind.
cons:
Understaffed 
Mismanaged 
Staff Under Appreciated
No Employee Incentives
Shady Management 
Inadequate training, the dept I worked for offered zero training and the workers were rude and hateful that they would have to take time to answer a question. It isn’t that they themselves are hateful but so overworked and short staffed that they are emotionally drained.

job_title: Staff RN in New Orleans, LA
pros: Love my teammates! There really is great teamwork on my unit. The company has tried their best to keep us safe during the pandemic and has not let go of anyone. They also stockpiled a bunch of PPE when they saw it getting bad.
cons: There is no room for growth unless I leave my unit/hospital. And the only way to make more money is to leave and come back. You can go work somewhere else for 6 months and get rehired making 3 or 4 more an hour.

job_title: Registered Nurse in New Orleans, LA
pros:
Beautiful facility.
Teaching hospital.
Incredible nightshift teamwork.
Easy to approach management.
Many learning opportunities.
cons:
Lots of drug seeking clientele.
Patient load (4:1)
Cafeteria closes before nightshift begins.
Lack of necessary equipment.
Dayshift. 
Unsafe for staff in ER waiting room (example: no glass, no walls, no metal detector).

review_title: Good PRN pay compared to other NOLA facilities
job_title: Registered Nurse in New Orleans, LA
pros: Great PRN pay, availability of hours (40 hours per week, even as a PRN employee). Also get shift and departmental differentials as a PRN employee.
cons: No benefits for PRN employees, but these employees are compensated appropriately. Can qualify for benefits after one year working at least 30 hours per week.

review_title: Proven problem solver with ability to operate in high stress situations.

pros: I'm one of the least lazy people that I know. I thrive on communication and the chain of command. I operate efficiently in high stress and actually welcome it.
cons: I can be too hard on the people who care about me the most. I am very black and white when it comes to expectations
